results.title: Noah's ark
results.creator_credit: John irvin, Stephen Jones and Babelsberg International Film Produktion
results.brief_description: Australia provides the backdrop for this loose retelling of the eternal story of biblical hero Noah (Jon Voight), the great flood that destroyed the world, and the ark that was built by Noah and his family and housed two of every animal species. This made for television movie was not well received by critics, despite its international cast of Jon Voight, Mary Steenburgen and F. Murray Abraham.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John irvin, Stephen Jones and Babelsberg International Film Produktion

results.title: 1950's volume one
results.creator_credit: Cyriel van den Hemel and Cable Connections Television Ltd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rock n’ roll: the greatest years”.
More than any other decade, the 1950’s is synonymous with the rock and roll revolution. This tape provides a nostalgic compilation of classics from the era, smattered with a healthy dose of gossip surrounding the performers. Songs on the tape include: “Heartbreak hotel”, Elvis Presley: “Problems”, Everly Brothers: “Great balls of fire”, Jerry Lee Lewis: “Lollipop”, Chordettes: “Turn me loose”, Cliff Richard: “Blueberry Hill”, Fats Domino: “Peggy Sue”, Buddy Holly: “Diana”, Paul Anka; “Teenage heaven”, Eddie Cochran: “Shakin’ all over”, Vince Taylor: “Memphis Tennessee”, Chuck Berry: “Blue suede shoes”, Carl Perkins: “Puttin’ on the style”, Lonnie Donegan: “Lucille”, Little Richard: “Please, please, please”, James Brown: “I’m not a juvenile delinquent”, Frankie Lymon: “Yes tonight Josephine”, Johnnie Ray: “Three cool cats”; Cliff Richard, Marty Wilde and Dickie Pride: “Wake up little Suzie”, Everly Brothers: “Only you”, The Platters: “I’m in love again”, Fats Domino: “Don’t be cruel (to a heart that’s true)”, Elvis Presley.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rock n’ roll: the greatest years”.
This tape provides a nostalgic compilation of classics from the era, smattered with a healthy dose of gossip surrounding the performers. Songs on the tape include: “Stars on 45”, Stars on 45: ‘Mr Tambourine man”, The Byrds: “I got you babe”, Sonny & Cher: “These boots are made for walking”, Nancy Sinatra: “The Sun ain’t gonna shine anymore”, Walker Brothers: “All or nothing”, Small Faces: “Good vibrations”, Beach Boys: “Whiter shade of pale”, Procol Harum: “Mighty Quinn”, Manfred Mann: “Cinderella Rockafella”, Esther & Obi Ofarim: “Baby come back”, Equals: “Fire”, Arthur Brown: “Those were the days”, Mary Hopkin: “Albatross”, Fleetwood Mac: “(If paradise is) half as nice”, Amen Corner: “In the year 2525”, Zager & Evans: “Something in the air”, Thunderclap Newman.

results.title: Kama sutra: a tale of love
results.creator_credit: Mira Nair, Lydia Dean Pilcher, Mirabai Films, NDF International, Pandora Films and Pony Canyon
results.brief_description: Centred on the text The Kama Sutra this is a film about class and politics in sixteenth century India - a lush melodrama, featuring explicit sexual posturing. Initially it is the story of two women: Maya, a rebellious servant girl and Tara her mistress and future queen, childhood friends who become adult rivals. Publicly humiliated during Tara’s nuptial celebrations, a vengeful Maya seduces the king prior to his wedding night. Consequently Maya is spurned and turned out into the street, despite the king’s burgeoning obsession for her. Maya has an affair with a sculptor of erotic deities, before training as a courtesan, returning to the palace as a professional seductress. Meanwhile the king has fallen into an opium addled, hedonistic stupor that threatens the future of the kingdom. Mira Nair’s (Mississippi Masala, Salaam Bombay!, Monsoon Wedding) film operates as a critique of the class system and is a tract about self-determination and sexual politics, but it is overwhelmed by a simplistic script and predictable character developments. Nair may have been reaching for a feminist interpretation of the classic erotic text, as well as a narrative about spiritual awakening, but the key joys here are the rich colourful palette and exotic setting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mira Nair, Lydia Dean Pilcher, Mirabai Films, NDF International, Pandora Films and Pony Canyon

results.title: Jalan jalan: a journey in Sudanese Java
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is a film without commentary but with all the sights and sounds, colour and tempo of life of the exotic Indonesian islands in the Java Sea. Here Jalan, Jalan can mean either going on a journey or simply taking a stroll. It is a film full of surprises in the bustling half-modern, half-ancient city of Jakarta, capital of the island republic, and in the lovely countryside. (An abridged and revised version of ‘Wet Earth and Warm People’ made for younger audiences.)

results.title: Jakob Gimpel, pianist: program No. 17
results.creator_credit: Paul Gordon, George Moskov and Official Films
results.brief_description: A Frederic Chopin recital performed by Polish-American pianist, Jakob Gimpel, featuring “Etude in E Major” (Opus 10, No. 3), “Waltz in C Sharp Minor” (Opus 64, No. 2) and “Mazurka in B Flat Major” (Opus 7, No. 1). Arranged by Roy Douglas into the ballet “Le Sylphide”.
